citation.article-title: Characterization of a new thermophilic sulfate-reducing bacterium: Thermodesulfovibrio yellowstonii, gen. nov. and sp. nov.: its phylogenetic relationship to Thermodesulfobacterium commune and their origins deep within the bacterial domain

p.s: Description of Thermodesulfovibrio yellowstonii sp. nov.
Thermodesulfovibrio yellowstonii (Yel.low.sto.ni.i, M.L. gen. n., of Yellowstone)
Curved rods or vibrios, 0.3 x 1.5 μm, motile by means of single polar flagella, gram-negative.
Strict anaerobe, temperature optimum 65°C with a range between 40°C and 70°C.
DNA base composition 29.5 (±1.0) mol% G + C.
With sulfate as an electron acceptor, electron donors are lactate, pyruvate, and hydrogen.
Acetate, propionate, butyrate, isobutyrate, ethanol, propanol, malate, fumarate, succinate, glucose, fructose, benzoate, valerate, isovalerate, and glutamate are not used as electron donors.
With lactate as electron donor, electron acceptors are sulfate, thiosulfate, and sulfite.
Nitrate, fumarate, and sulfur are not used.
Habitat: anaerobic niches associated with hydrothermal vent water.
Type strain YP87 isolated from hydrothermal vent water in Sedge Bay of Yellowstone Lake, Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, USA. Thermodesulfovibrio yellowstonii, ATCC 51303.
